title: Law of Chile
text:
The legal system of <a href="Chile">Chile</a> belongs to the <a href="Civil%20Law%20%28legal%20system%29">Continental Law</a> tradition.
The basis for its <a href="public%20law">public law</a> is the 1980 <a href="Constitution%20of%20Chile">Constitution</a>, reformed in 1989 and 2005. According to it Chile is a "democratic republic". There is a clear <a href="Separation%20of%20powers">separation of functions</a>, between the President of the Republic, the Congress, the judiciary and a Constitutional Court. See <a href="Politics%20of%20Chile">Politics of Chile</a>.
On the other hand, private relationships are governed, mainly, by the <a href="Civil%20Code%20%28Chile%29">Chilean Civil Code</a>, most of which has not been amended in 150 years. There are also several laws outside the Code that deal with most of the business law.
Public law.
Constitution.
The current Political Constitution of the Republic of Chile, approved by Chilean voters in a tightly controlled <a href="plebiscite">plebiscite</a> on September 11, 1980 under <a href="Augusto%20Pinochet">Augusto Pinochet</a>, and made effective on March 11, 1981, has been amended in 1989, 1991, 1994, 1997, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2003 and 2005.
In 2005 over 50 reforms were approved, which eliminated some of the remaining undemocratic areas of the text, such as the existence of non-elected Senators (appointed senators, or <a href="senators%20for%20life">senators for life</a>) and the inability of the President to remove the Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces. These reforms led the President to controversially declare Chile's transition to democracy as complete.
There is a <a href="constitutional%20court">constitutional court</a> ("Tribunal Constitucional") with the competence to declare a singular law "not applicable" to an individual case ("inaplicabilidad por inconstitucionalidad") and, having declared that at least once, the unconstitutionality of that law in general.
Administrative law.
The <a href="President%20of%20Chile">President of the Republic</a> must fulfill the administrative function, in collaboration with several <a href="Ministries%20of%20Chile">ministries</a> or other authorities with "ministerial rank". Each Ministry has one or more sub secretaries. The actual "satisfaction of public needs" is performed through <a href="public%20services">public services</a>, dependant or at least related to one of those sub secretaries.
All Ministries and public services have a body of workers or administrative personnel ("funcionarios públicos").
<a href="Public%20property">Public property</a> is subject to privileges and burdens, because it serves public purposes. The sea, rivers and lakes, mines and natural reservations belong to the state and may be used by "anyone", but when individual exploitation is possible then it is in the hands of privates. On the other hand, buildings, cars and other supplies that are necessary for the work of public agencies are also property of the state.
Public entities act through administrative procedures, that is, processes with formal stages where opportunities to deliver evidence and exercise appeals are granted to the citizens. The recent basic law of administrative procedures deals with most of the general matters pertaining the administrative procedures of all public entities.
There is not a singular <a href="administrative%20court">administrative court</a> to deal with actions against the administrative entities, but several specialized courts and procedures of review. However, civil courts have jurisdiction over all matters that are not in the scope of other tribunal, such as <a href="public%20liability">public liability</a> and the overturn of single administrative acts.
Regulation.
Since the privatization of most economic activities in the 1980s, the President and the independent agencies became the main policy makers regarding the <a href="regulation">regulation</a> of the economy, subordinated to <a href="legislation">legislation</a>.
The exploitation of <a href="Mining">mines</a> and <a href="water">water</a> resources is given in concession to private entrepreneurs.
All activities that can have a significant impact on the <a href="environment%20%28biophysical%29">environment</a> must obtain an administrative <a href="authorization">authorization</a> and are subject to heavy regulation by several different agencies.
There are <a href="Government%20agency">agencies</a> ("Superintendencias") dealing with:
Private law.
Civil Code.
The Civil Code of the Republic of Chile is the work of the Chilean-Venezuelan jurist and legislator <a href="Andr%C3%A9s%20Bello">Andrés Bello</a>. After several years of individual work (though officially presented as the work of multiple Congress commissions), Congress passed the Civil Code into law on 14 December 1855, and came into force on 1 January 1857. The Code has kept in force since then though it has been the object of numerous alterations.
The main modernisations the code has undergone have affected <a href="family%20law">family law</a> and the law of <a href="Inheritance">succession</a>s. On one hand, these reforms have introduced more equal relations between men and women and, on the other, they have eliminated discriminations between children born <a href="Legitimacy%20%28family%20law%29">from married couples</a> and those born extramaritally.
Being part of the <a href="civil%20law%20%28legal%20system%29">civil law</a> tradition, there is no obedience to <a href="precedent">precedent</a> in Chilean law. Nevertheless, <a href="Sentence%20%28law%29">sentences</a> of a higher court can be <a href="appeal">appeal</a>ed to the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20Chile">Supreme Court</a> based in the "erroneous application of the law", thus being able to deliver uniform decisions in controversial matters of law." See <a href="Judiciary%20of%20Chile">Judiciary of Chile</a>".
Commerce.
Though the Commerce Code of 1868 was the main source of business law, nowadays the legislation is widely spread in many legislative bodies.
For instance, both the Civil Code and the Commerce Code deal with the basic matters of enterprises, but <a href="corporations">corporations</a> and <a href="limited%20liability">limited liability</a> enterprises have a statute of its own.
Recently the law of <a href="bankruptcy">bankruptcy</a> has been incorporated in the Commerce Code, in a process of re-<a href="Codification%20%28law%29">codification</a>.
Matters such as <a href="banking">banking</a> and the <a href="stock%20exchange">stock exchange</a> are strongly regulated by <a href="government%20agencies">government agencies</a> and therefore are subject to public scrutiny. Recently, these agencies have fined important executives for <a href="insider%20trading">insider trading</a> <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20110718203740/http%3A//www.elclarin.cl/index.php%3Foption%3Dcom_content%26amp%3Btask%3Dview%26amp%3Bid%3D10143%26amp%3BItemid%3D47"></a>.
Criminal law.
Since the year 2000, Chilean <a href="criminal%20procedure">criminal procedure</a> is experiencing one of the most important legal reforms of the country's history, completely replacing an inquisitory procedure by an accusatory system, very similar to that of <a href="Germany">Germany</a> or the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. While the prosecution is in charge of an autonomous authority ("Ministerio Público"), the actual judgement is made by a collegiate court ("Tribunal de Juicio Oral en lo Penal"). <a href="Trial%20%28law%29">Trials</a> are public and verbal. However, the law grants several alternatives to the <a href="defendant">defendant</a> so as to avoid the trial, but, at the same time, grant the victim's satisfaction and the public safety.
The Chilean <a href="Criminal%20Code">Criminal Code</a>, which defines the conducts that constitute an offense and the applicable conviction, dates back to 1874. It was greatly inspired by the Spanish Code of 1848 and the Belgian Code of 1867. The Code has been widely criticized, and the Ministry of Justice is studying a complete replacement by the year 2010 <a href="http%3A//www.politicacriminal.cl/n_01/pdf_01/d_1.pdf"></a>.
